Comments_List: I feel like I left the course having a good sense of the recent history of the subfield of American religious history. I also think my ability to write a book review improved, as did my ability to put two books in conversation with each other and with the historiography.

This course provided a help introduction to the academic literature on American religion. I appreciated the wide breadth of readings, including Professor Wenger's desire to have us engage with a variety of disciplinary/methodological approaches to the study of religion. I found the assignments -- two academic book reviews and a final paper that combined historiography and primary source analysis -- to be useful practice for writing styles common in academic history.

I gained an understanding of historiography and the art of writing history that I did not have before. The focus lenses of history and the ways in which they affect representation and interpretation were enlightening.
I feel like I have a broad understanding of the state of the field in a way that makes me feel confident moving forward.
Practice in critical evaluation of recent historical texts.

Working through the intricacies of a single book per week 
Constructive seminar participation 
Overview of American religion that can be parlayed into dissertation research 
Structural comparisons between different intellectual projects 
Book reviews

I think the student interventions were extremely helpful. They helped contextualize the readings for the week and exposed me to a wider literature. I also thought the experience of presenting was helpful as well. For the final paper, a preliminary assignment like a paper proposal would have been helpful. It would have encouraged me to start thinking about the final earlier.

Strengths:
-Great, varied reading list
-Prof. Wenger was a good discussion facilitator
-Very manageable workload
-Class presentations on related books were helpful for expanding knowledgeable of the field

Weaknesses:
-Could have been more effort to include books on non-Christian religious traditions

I thought this course was excellent! It might be helpful to have a brief introduction to the theory of history/historiography at the beginning of the course, but I recognize that other student enrolled might not need such a survey.

Too little time devoted to each reading.  A number of the readings would have warranted several class meetings.  Needed to devote more time to identifying exactly what historians mean by "intervention."  What do they mean by a "primary" sources?  Would have appreciated more direction for final paper.

This course was fantastic overall and was often the highlight of my week! The only thing I would recommend is to have a proposal due a few weeks before paper submission that would allow us to flesh out some ideas and get our bibliographies in shape before we head in to the maelstrom of finals season.
I would highly recommend this class for those interested in American religious history
Yes. This was a great introduction to the historiography surrounding American religion.

Yes, I would recommend this course. I feel like I left the course with a good overview of the history of the subfield and the various ways that people have written American religious history in the past few years.

I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone interested in studying the history of American religion at the graduate level. It was a very helpful introductory class and I now feel that I am much more familiar with the literature in this area. I also have a better sense of the kinds of methodological approaches that can be employed to study American religion, and of some of the major challenges/controversies in the field.
Yes, I thought the course was excellent. If a student is looking for a grounding in American History in the context of religious studies this course is perfect.
Absolutely.  I think it should be cross-listed in the Div School for MAR students to get better acquainted with religious studies more broadly.

I would take another class from this instructor.

This is not a course for everyone.  It is an advanced seminar intended for graduate students in American Studies and History.  Perhaps too specialized for M.Div. or S.T.M. students without a strong background in Church History.  Again, rather intense reading (it is, after all, a "reading course"); not as much feedback as I personally needed. Perhaps should require one-on-one with each student after second book review.
Absolutely! Not only did it allow me to find a group of fantastic, committed graduate students, but Tisa is such a generative thinker who is generous with her insights and time.
